{{About||the 1978 movie with the same title|King of the Gypsies (film)|the band Gipsy Kings|Gipsy Kings}} {{Romani people}} {{Tone|date=March 2016}} The title '''King of the Gypsies''' has been claimed or given over the centuries to many different people. It is both culturally and geographically specific. It may be inherited, acquired by acclamation or action, or simply claimed. The extent of the power associated with the title varied; it might be limited to a small group in a specific place, or many people over large areas. In some cases the claim was clearly a public relations exercise. As the term [[wikt:gypsy|Gypsy]] is also used in many different ways the ''King of the Gypsies'' may be someone with no connection with the [[Romani people]]. In the early 1970s, it was decided, at the First Annual Romani Meeting that the term Gypsy would no-longer be used to describe themselves. They voted for the term Roma to be used.
It has also been suggested that in places where they were persecuted by local authorities the "King of the Gypsies" is an individual, usually of low standing, who places himself in the risky position of an ad hoc liaison between the Romani and the gadje (non-Romani). The arrest of such a "King" limited the harm to the Romani people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wcl.american.edu/hrbrief/09/3roma.cfm |title=Human Rights Brief Human Rights Brief |website=Wcl.american.edu |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref>
==Scotland== ===John (Johnnie) Faa=== {{main|John Faa}} Johnnie Faa of Dunbar was leader of the 'Egyptians', or Gypsies, in Scotland. Faa was granted a letter under the [[Privy Seal]] from [[James IV of Scotland|King James IV]] in February 1540, which was renewed in 1553. It was addressed to "oure louit Johnne Faw, lord and erle of Litill Egipt" establishing his authority over all Gypsies in Scotland and calling on all [[sheriffs]] in the country to assist him "in executione of justice upoun his company and folkis", who were to "conforme to the lawis of Egipt".
He is resurrected in fiction in S. R. Crockett's ''The Raiders'' and in Philip Pullman's trilogy ''[[His Dark Materials]]''.
===Johnne Wanne=== Son and successor of Johnnie Faa, Johnne Wanne was granted Royal authority over all "Egyptians" in Scotland in May 1540. Records showed that by 1612 the Faa family had extended as far as [[Shetland]]. However, the initial tolerance of Gypsies did not last. In 1623 eight leaders of the Gypsies were hanged on the Burgh Muir, six of whom were of the Faa line. In the 1650s they were amongst those [[Penal transportation|transported]] to [[Virginia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sacred-texts.com/neu/roma/gft/index.htm |title=Gypsy Folk Tales Index |website=Sacred-texts.com |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref>
=== Patrick Faa === Patrick was the first recorded Gypsy King at [[Kirk Yetholm]]. Along with seven other Gypsies he was "sentenced to be transported to the Queen's American for life."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Anonymous|first=|date=September 1817|title=NOTICES CONCERNING THE SCOTTISH GYPSIES |url=|journal=Edinburgh Monthly Magazine|volume=1 (September)|pages=616|via=}}</ref>
=== William Faa I === King William I, known as 'Gleed Nickit Wull' because of a twist in the shape of his throat, was born about 1700, and died at Coldingham in 1784, aged around 84. He fathered 24 children by three wives.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scottishgypsies.co.uk/will.html|title=Will Faa, The Faa Family, Famous Gypsies|website=www.scottishgypsies.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref> His death at Colingham is recounted by William Smith, the Baillie at Kelso, who states that "When old Will Faa was upwards of eighty years of age, he called on me in Kelso, in his way to Edinburgh, telling me that he was going to Edinburgh to see the laird... before he died," and also that after successfully completing this visit "he only got the length of Colingham, when he was taken ill and died."<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Waverley Anecdotes: Illustrative of the Incidents, Characters, and Scenery, Described in the Novels and Romances, of Sir Walter Scott|last=Scott|first=Walter|publisher=J. Cochrane and J. McCrone|year=1833|isbn=|location=London|pages=217–218}}</ref> Will claimed to be descended from Johnnie Faa, Lord of Little Egypt.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scottishgypsies.co.uk/will.html|title=Will Faa, The Faa Family, Famous Gypsies|website=www.scottishgypsies.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref>
===William Faa II=== Will Faa, "King of the Gypsies", died in [[Kirk Yetholm]] on 9 October 1847, aged 96. He was the son of William Faa I. William Faa was an innkeeper (owned "The Queen") and footballer who lived at "The Gypsy Palace" off the Green, and entertained visitors there. The ''Kelso Mail'' carried his obituary entitled "Death of a Gypsy King", which said he was "always accounted a more respectable character than any of his tribe, and could boast of never having been in gaol during his life." His house continued to be a tourist attraction, and there was reportedly an "Old Palace" on the other side of Kirk Yetholm Green. William died without issue in 1847 when the 'Crown' passed to his sister Esther's husband Charles Blythe (1775-1861). Charles was an educated man who did much to live up to his role. On his death in 1861 there was a tussle between his many children for the right to be monarch. The role went to his daughter Esther Faa Blythe who reigned until 1883 when the gypsy culture was in serious decline. Following a gap of several years in 1898 one of her sons Charles Rutherford was persuaded to accept the office and a ceremonial Gypsy Coronation was held in 1898. By this stage the role was largely an attempt to boost tourism. Charles died in 1902 and the title has not been re-established. An Edinburgh housewife is now thought to be the present 'Queen'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discovertheborders.co.uk/places/212.html |title=The Gypsy Palace, Kirk Yetholm, Scotland |website=Discovertheborders.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scottishgypsies.co.uk/ |title=The Scottish Gypsies of Scotland |website=Scottishgypsies.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref><ref>‘’Journal Gypsy Lore Soc.’’ 3rd ser.ii 370-1 quoted in ‘’English Genealogy’’ A. R. Wagner</ref> A lancet and case belonging to William Faa II can be found in the collections of the National Museum Scotland.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nms.ac.uk/explore-our-collections/collection-search-results/?item_id=25638|title=Case, lancet|website=National Museums Scotland|language=en|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref>
=== Charles Faa Blythe I === Charles Faa Blythe was a brother-in-law to William Faa II, and when he died without issue the title of King of the Gypsies was passed to Charles, husband of his sister, Esther. Charles was born in 1775 and died in 1861. He was crowned King, by the local blacksmith, George Gladstone, on 25 October 1847, aged at least 70 years.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scottishgypsies.co.uk/charles.html|title=Charles Blyth I, The Faa Family, Famous Gypsies|website=www.scottishgypsies.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref> He was succeeded by his daughter, Esther Faa Blythe, who was born in the early years of the 1800s and died on 12 July 1883.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scottishgypsies.co.uk/esther3.html|title=Esther Faa Blythe, The Faa Family, Famous Gypsies|website=www.scottishgypsies.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref>
=== Charles Faa Blyth II === Born around 1825, Charles Rutherford (known as Charles Faa Blythe II), was a son to Esther Faa Bythe, the Gypsy Queen. Between the death of Esther Faa Blyth in 1883 and the accession of Charles II in 1898, there was no Gypsy royalty crowned at Kirk Yetholm. His coronation ceremony was really a pageant, with all the locals dressing up for the benefit of the photographers. Many photographs of the occasion still exist.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scottishgypsies.co.uk/charles22.html|title=Charles Faa Blyth II, The Faa Family, Famous Gypsies|website=www.scottishgypsies.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-07-21}}</ref>
===William (Billy) Marshall=== William (Billy) Marshall (1672-1792) died aged 120, lived in Minnigaff, Kirkcudbrightshire, South West Scotland. Caird of Barullion, King of the Gypsies of the Western Lowlands for 89 years. Served as a soldier at the Battle of the Boyne for William of Orange, Battle of Blenheim. Returned to Scotland where he had an army of 200 followers who ruled the land between Ayr and Dumfries and fought battles at Newton of Ayr, Brig O Doon and Alloway. He was a Protestant, Covenanter, and Leveller. He and his army would champion, the poor, the dispossessed, and steal, disrupt, and organize smuggling activities in cattle, sheep, horses, brandy, whisky, tea, against Jacobites, Landlords, and those that were not locals who were known to him. He was an accomplished craftsman of horn spoons, cups, pots. He is buried in the graveyard at St Cuthbert's Church in [[Kirkcudbright]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Billy Marshall - the Scottish King of the Gypsies|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk:80/education/beyond/factsheets/makhist/makhist10_prog7c.shtml|publisher=BBC|accessdate=23 June 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041214200506/http://www.bbc.co.uk/education/beyond/factsheets/makhist/makhist10_prog7c.shtml|archivedate=14 December 2004|deadurl=yes|df=}}</ref> 6 February 2018, AJMcC, The Tinkler Gypsies of Galloway, by Andrew McCormick
==France== ===Florent Léglise=== Often referred as the Ecclesiast, his origins remain unknown but research indicates that he lived around the french territories of the South Gironde. Admired for his famous mystical beard, he became one of the central symbolic representations of authority for french gypsies, as many tales and legends were created and put together from diverse episodes taken from his life (e.g. Catherine's street hidden Church, the Ecclesiast and the last Gitardise, The drummer and the prince, the good, the bad and the Church, etc.). He was nominated by his predecessor, Joni Ali, in 1993 after the battle of the Golden Veal of Bazas, and was crowned after the death of its mentor on the 5th of may of the following year (Joni Ali's Day).
==England== ===Leaders identified in Martin Markall=== The short book ''Martin Markall, [[Beadle]] of the [[Bridewell]]'' was published in London in 1610. The author is given as "S.R.", who is usually identified as [[Samuel Rid]] the author of ''The Art of Jugling or Legerdemaine'', a later book of rogue literature<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Notes and Queries |volume=Eleventh |issue=287 |title=Gypsies in England |publisher=George Bell |date=April 28, 1855 |location=London |page=326}}</ref> promised in Martin Markall. The book is of dubious veracity, and large sections are taken from the works of [[Thomas Dekker (poet)|Thomas Dekker]],<ref>{{cite book |title=Gypsy Identities 1500-2000: From Egipcyans and Moon-men to the Ethnic Romany |first=David |last=Mayall |publisher=Routledge |date=Oct 9, 2003 |page=69}}</ref> although [[Frank Aydelotte]], who dates the book to 1608, calls it mostly original.<ref>{{cite book |title=Elizabethan Rogues and Vagabonds |first=Frank |last=Aydelotte |page=unnumbered |publisher=Routledge |edition=5th |year=2013}}</ref> It includes what purports to be a list of the leaders of "the regiment of rogues", which echoed the genealogies of prominent families. It will be seen that in reality few had anything to do with Gypsies, but they are indicative of the context in which some of the Kings of the Gypsies were identified.
====John Mendall==== aka [[Jack Cade]], aka John Mortimer, who led a rebellion of men from Kent who camped at Blackheath outside London in 1450. After his rebellion a reward was offered for him, and he was captured and killed in Kent.
====Bluebeard and Hugh Roberts==== Both soldiers who had served in France. Bluebeard was captured and executed shortly after being made "their captain". Roberts then gathered about 100 "rakehells and vagabonds" in Kent who were joined by 400 "masterless men". Together they joined Jack Cade and entered [[Southwark]]. After the end of Cade's rebellion Roberts took to the woods with a small group living by theft, according to set rules of their own. After a year living like this these "Roberdsmen" dispersed throughout England, vowing to meet every three years, and joining other "commotions and rebellions". Roberts also went "roving" and "kept his court" until he was killed in 1461.
====Jenkin Cowdiddle==== Was chosen by the remaining "Roberdsmen" at "their wonted place of meeting" "by general assent". He was "a wandering rogue", "much given to swearing, drunkenness and lechery . . . stout of stomach, audacious and fierce". He claimed ''[[droit du seigneur]]'', and ordained that all beggars spent their weekly earnings in full every Saturday night. Rid says that he fought with "300 tattered knaves" in the rebellion in the South West of England against [[Edward IV]] and was killed at the [[Battle of Tewkesbury]] (1471). Unlike Roberts, who may have been a real character, this Cowdiddle seems to have been a complete fiction.
====Spising==== Not deterred, the remaining "Roberdsmen" "hie them to their rendezvous . . . and there, with the full consent of the whole company, they chose one Spising to be his successor". Spising is given no first name. He is credited with ordering that all begging wanderers be "stalled as a rogue" by "the Chief Commander then being", paying a fee in beer, though this was excused if his father and grandfather had been rogues. Spising joined the larger rebellion by Thomas Neville, the [[Bastard of Fauconberg]]. He led a band attacking [[Aldgate]], and was nearly successful, until parts of his group were trapped by the fall of the [[portcullis]]. Spising is reputed to have ruled 11 years before being hanged for a murder in [[Wombourn]], [[Staffordshire]], having escaped the same fate earlier by seeking [[sanctuary]] in [[Westminster Abbey]]. There is a historical record of a Spising as leader of an [[Essex]] contingent of Neville's uprising, but he was executed after it, and his head exhibited on Aldgate.
====Puff Dick==== Was the next elected, an expert at cheating with [[loaded dice]], and excelled in "all manner of vice". He repeated Cowdiddle's requirement for thieves and beggars to spend their ill-gotten gains and not save them. Rid says he ruled for 8 years before dying of "the [[French pox|[French] pox]] and Neapolitan scurf". Like Cowdiddle, Dick seems to have been wholly fictional.
====Laurence Crossbiter (aka Long Laurence)==== Laurence Crossbiter was the next elected leader, a serving man aged 50–60. His art was "crossbiting"; theft from the customers of whores. He is also reported to have died "his bowels . . . eaten out with the pox while he was yet alive". Rid described him as cowardly and slavish for failing to come to the aid of the rebel [[Perkin Warbeck]].
====Richard Skelton==== Was one of Warbeck's counsellors, "a noted knave". He was next "led to the wonted place of meeting, and there solemnly stalled a rogue and made their general". He is described as formerly having been a [[tailor]] in [[Taunton]], [[Somerset]] "of proud and haughty disposition", and have "lived in this new government" until 1501. A Skelton was recorded by [[Sir Francis Bacon]] as a counsellor to Warbeck, but he says nothing of his activities after the rebellion.
====Cock Lorel==== Was elected his successor "by the General Council". Cock Lorel was "the most notorious knave that ever lived" who ruled until 1533. He professed the trade of a tinker to cover his thefts. Rid says that his knaveries are recorded in an old manuscript kept as "Maunders’ Hall", giving the rogue community a similar structure of that of the trade [[guilds]]. Cock Lorel was the great mythical leader of Tudor rogues. His name means just that, "cock" being leader, and "lorel" or losel" meaning rascal. He first appears about 1500 in "Cock Lorel's Boat", and is mentioned in [[Robert Copland]]'s ''The Highway to the Spitalhouse'' (1535). He is credited with approving John Awdesley's ''The Fraternity of Vagabonds'', (1561), in which he is given as the creator of the Twenty Five Orders of Knaves, reproduced in [[Thomas Harman]]'s ''Warning for Common Cursitors'' and many other works of rogue literature. There is no record of any real individual on whom he was based. Cock Lorel is credited with having held a meeting with the leader of the Egyptians, Giles Hather, at their base at [[Peak Cavern|The Devils Arse Apeak]] in [[Derbyshire]]. Rid claims that at this meeting they devised a new and secret language [[Thieves' Cant]], "to the end that their cozenings, knaveries, and villainies might not so easily be perceived and known".<ref>Rid, Samuel (1610). ''Martin Markall, the Beadle of Bridewell''. as quoted in {{cite book |title=Becoming Criminal: Transversal Performance and Cultural Dissidence in Early Modern England (Google eBook) |first=Bryan |last=Reynolds |page=unnumbered |publisher=JHU Press |date=Apr 1, 2003}}</ref>
====Giles Hather==== Became head of the regiment or fellowship of Egyptians in the north about 1528. These, Rid says, travelled in groups of more than a hundred men and women, with horses, their faces blacked, and practised [[legerdemain]] and [[fortune telling]] by [[palmistry]], delighting the common people with their clothes.
====Kit Callot==== "the Queen of the Egypties" accompanied Giles Hather, according to Rid. These names were traditional; Hather is mentioned by Thomas Awdesley (1561). "Kit" and "Callot" as names can be traced back to [[Piers Plowman]]. Although Tudor government, both local and national, took a close interest in the Egyptians there is no record of the names in their records.
===Other leaders=== ====Boswells==== The Boswells were for centuries one of England's largest and most important Gypsy families. The Boswell clan were a large extended family of [[Romani people|Travellers]], and in old [[Nottinghamshire dialect]] the word ''bos'll'' was used as a term for Travellers and Romani in general.
=====Haniel Boswell===== Was the son of Francis Boswell.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.garenewing.co.uk/family/hodgkins.html |title=The Romani Line - Boswell, Sherriff & Hodgkins or Hodgkinson |website=Garenewing.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref>
=====Jacob Rewbrey===== "Alias king of the Gypsies", from the St Margaret's [[Westminster]], was tried at the [[Old Bailey]] on 28 August 1700 for theft with violence and highway robbery. It was alleged he had robbed "one Rebecca Sellers, near the High way, . . . taking from her 3 Gold-rings, and 9 s. in Money" in January of that year. The Jury found him Guilty of theft, but not Robbery, as "It appeared that he juggled [tricked] her out of it." He was sentenced to [[Penal transportation]].<ref>{{Old Bailey|defendant=Jacob Rewbrey|trialdate=28 August 1700|id=t17000828-63|accessdate=28 January 2018}}</ref>
=====James Boswell===== Is buried in [[Rossington]], near [[Doncaster]] in [[Yorkshire]]. Langdale's "Topographical Dictionary of Yorkshire" (1822), says: "In the church yard, was a stone, the two ends of which are now remaining, where was interred the body of James Bosvill the King of the Gypsies, who died January 30, 1708. For a number of years, it was a custom of Gypsies from the south, to visit his tomb annually, and there perform some of their accustomed rites; one of which was to pour a flagon of ale upon the grave." This is similar to the ritual of "stalling the rogue" mentioned by [[Thomas Harman]] and in ''The Beggars Bush'' and by [[Bampfylde Moore Carew]].
A tradition was reported of annual visits to the grave of Charles Boswell near Doncaster for more than 100 years into the 1820s, including a rite of pouring a flagon of hot ale into the tomb. This may be same person.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.donny.co.uk/Doncaster/news/index.php3?ID=376 |title=Doncaster News and Features: Bizarre Doncaster: Ghosts and Hauntings, on Donny Online |website=Donny.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref><ref>[[Brian Vesey-Fitzgerald]] Gypsies of Britain, The Country Book Club, 1951, quoting Edward Miller History and Antiquities of Doncaster</ref><ref>John Wainwright, History and Antiquities of Doncaster and Consborough, Sheffield, Basil Blackwell., 1829</ref> the grave is situated by the main door leading to the church, shaded by a dark oak tree. It is now covered in moss, but is still readable. The words "King Of The Gypsies" will lie there for ever more, whereas the mystery of the black cat is still unsolved. – information on the grave by A. Needham – P. Needham, of St. Michaels church.''
=====Henry Boswell===== "King of the Gypsies" died in 1760 at the age of 90 and was buried at [[Ickleford]] near [[Hitchin]], [[Hertfordshire]] at the church of St. Catherine, as were his wife and granddaughter. Royal National and Commercial Directory and Topography of Herts, Pigot & Co., London, 1839<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pjoiner.demon.co.uk/genuki/HRT/Ickleford/index.html|title=GENUKI - Ickleford|date=11 October 2006|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=8 October 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061011062618/http://www.pjoiner.demon.co.uk/genuki/HRT/Ickleford/index.html|archivedate=11 October 2006|df=}}</ref>
=====Edmund Mashiter===== aka "Old Honey", died in [[Bolton]], [[Lancashire]] in 1811 aged 90. He was reported to have been "justly entitled the King of Beggars", having been on the road for 70 years. He was reported to have been the son of a schoolmaster, and well educated, but to have taken to the road by choice, and maintained a wandering life until he became bedridden. <ref>''The Gentleman's Magazine'', 1 March 1811.</ref>
=====Henry Boswell===== The "King of the Gypsies" died in 1824 [[Stamford, Lincolnshire]].<ref>''Rutland & Stamford Mercury'' 15 October 1824 p3 column 1</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lincolnshire.gov.uk/section.asp?docId=45657 |title=Gypsies | Lincolnshire County Council |website=Lincolnshire.gov.uk |date=2012-06-07 |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref>
=====Louis Boswell===== Louis Boswell was buried at [[St. Laurence and All Saints Church, Eastwood|Eastwood church]], [[Southend-on-Sea]] in 1835. In the Burial Register he is described as a "Traveller aged 42" – "This man known as the King of the Gypsies was interred in the presence of a vast concourse of spectators".<ref>{{cite web|title=King of Gypsies Edward Boswell|url=http://gypsyjib.wetpaint.com/page/KING+OF+GYPSIES+EDWARD+BOSWELL |publisher=Rromani djib|accessdate=22 January 2011}}</ref>
====Non Boswells==== =====Unknown, Calne===== In the churchyard of [[St Mary's Church, Calne|St Mary's]] parish church, [[Calne]], [[Wiltshire]], a tomb commemorating an unknown King of the Gypsies is set in the wall.<ref>{{cite web|title=Calne|url=http://www.gazetteandherald.co.uk/leisure/outabout/tourism/townsandvillages/wtcalne/|website=Wiltshire Gazette and Herald|accessdate=18 March 2016}}</ref>
=====Harry Burton===== Described as "King of the Gypsies", died in the [[Workhouse]] in [[Wincanton]], [[Somerset]] aged 94 in 1847.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wincanton-online.com/wincanton.htm|title=Wincanton|date=5 April 2005|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=8 October 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050405030917/http://www.wincanton-online.com/wincanton.htm|archivedate=5 April 2005|df=}}</ref>
=====Matty Cooper===== Taught the [[Romani language]] in the 1870s to [[Charles Godfrey Leland]] (1824–1903), the American folklorist and founder of the Gypsy Lore Society. Leland claimed Cooper was the King of the Gypsies in England.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.themystica.com/mystica/articles/l/Leland_charles_godfrey.html |title=Leland, Charles Godfrey |website=Themystica.com |date=1903-03-20 |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref>
=====Xavier Petulengro/ Smith ===== Was described as the King of the Gypsies, in an account of a Romani wedding at [[Baildon]] in [[Yorkshire]] in 1937 between his son Leon Petulengro/ Smith and Illeana Smith both of Colchester Essex. According to the caption of a photograph [[Xavier Petulengro]] cut the hands of the couple to mingle their blood during the ceremony. After their wedding the couple went north to Blackpool. During the war Leon was in the RAF and Ileana (Eileen) was a staff car driver for ICI. The marriage was dissolved in 1947 in Nottingham. Baildon was a famous fair and meeting place for Gypsies. Petulengro/ Smith was well known as a broadcaster on Gypsy subjects. His son Leon Petulengro/ Smith wrote for the "Woman's Own" magazine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scienceandsociety.co.uk/results.asp?image=10249897&wwwflag=3&imagepos=1 |title=Stock photo and image search by Science & Society Picture Library |website=Scienceandsociety.co.uk |date=2008-04-23 |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref>
=====Gilderoy Scamp===== Born in [[Orpington]], [[Kent]] early 20th century. Lived in [[Folkestone]], Kent.<ref>''Gilderoy Scamp – King of the Gypsies'', Linda Hayward, ''Rromani Routes'' Volume 4 No 7 June 2000</ref>
=====Louis Welch===== Louis Welch of [[Darlington]] was described by British media as the "King of the Gypsies", a title given to the best bare-knuckled boxer in the [[Romanichal]] - mainly from the UK, and France community, following an alleged attack by six knife-wielding men, possibly from a rival band of travellers, in [[Cumbria]]. He refused to give evidence against his attackers, saying it was "against the travellers' code of honour", and a retrial was ordered after the jury failed to reach a verdict.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/8552394.stm|title=Retrial over 'King of Gypsies' boxer attack in Cumbria|publisher=BBC|date=2010-03-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/news/673657-king-of-the-gypsies-injured-in-knife-attack |title='King of the Gypsies' injured in knife attack | Metro News |website=Metro.co.uk |date=2009-05-27 |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/5025032._Ignore_whims_of_King_of_the_Gipsies_/|title=Ignore whims of King of the Gipsies|publisher=The Northern Echo|date=2010-02-24}}</ref>
==Wales== ===Abram Wood=== Abram Wood was the head of a family of Welsh gypsies in the 1700s. They were musicians, and spoke an old Romani dialect.<ref>{{cite web|title=Facts About Wales & the Welsh: Welsh gypsies were the last to speak Romani in Europe|url=http://britannia.com/celtic/wales/facts/facts7.html|publisher=Wales on Britannia|accessdate=23 June 2017}}</ref>
==Norway== ===Karoli family=== In the 1980s, Polykarp Karoli began styling himself "King of all Gypsies in Norway".<ref>''Aftenposten'' 1989.12.27: ''Sigøynerkongen tatt i København''</ref>
In 1990, while most of the family was serving prison time, Polykarp's grandson Martin Erik Karoli proclaimed himself "King of One Million Gypsies", claiming to be slated for a hundreds of years old crowning ceremony in Central Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web.retriever-info.com/services/webdocument.html?documentId=00230420080411105035364&serviceId=2 |title=Retriever |website=Web.retriever-info.com |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref> After Polykarp's death in 2001, his two sons publicly rivalled for the title "King of All Gypsies in The World", estimating 47.8 million subjects throughout the world and citing various ancient ceremonies and royal registries.<ref>''VG'' 2001.08.11: ''Jeg er den nye kongen!''</ref>
==Italy== ===Scaramuccia=== This "King of the Gypsies" is suggested as a possible model for "A Grotesque Head" of the sketches of human physiognomy by [[Leonardo da Vinci]], dated to (c.1503-07). [[Giorgio Vasari]] reported that Leonardo had done a drawing of "the Gypsy Captain Scaramuccia" which Vasari possessed, but it is not known what happened to it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chch.ox.ac.uk/index.php?option=com_content&task=blogcategory&id=21&Itemid=234 |title=Christ Church, Oxford University |website=Chch.ox.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref>
==Romania== ===Iulian Rădulescu=== In 1993, Iulian Rădulescu proclaimed himself "Emperor of the Roma Everywhere".<ref>[[:ro:Iulian Rădulescu]]</ref>
===Florin Cioabă=== [[Florin Cioabă]] acquired the title "King of the Roma Everywhere" in 1997 from his father Ioan Cioabă who had claimed the title in 1992. Reports in 2003 that Cioabă, a [[Pentecostal]] Minister, had married off his own daughter at the age of 12 (or 14) caused uproar in the western media. The [[UN]] Economic and Social Council visited him in 1999 when preparing a report on Racism and Intolerance and described him as devoting himself to economic activity to support community projects, and exerting "[[moral authority]]" and having "some influence" as a councillor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cidcm.umd.edu/inscr/mar/chronology.asp?groupId=36003|title=MAR - Data - Chronology for Roma in Romania|date=28 August 2004|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=8 October 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040828191802/http://www.cidcm.umd.edu/inscr/mar/chronology.asp?groupId=36003|archivedate=28 August 2004|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.developmentinaction.org/newspages/index/64.php|title=Development in Action - The thorny issues surrounding the practice of child marriage – cultural tradition or economic necessity?|date=26 December 2004|website=Developmentinaction.org|accessdate=8 October 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041226114518/http://www.developmentinaction.org/newspages/index/64.php|archivedate=26 December 2004|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.soros.org/initiatives/health/focus/roma/articles_publications/articles/underground_20060727/sibiu_20060711.pdf |title=Open Society Foundations |publisher=Soros.org |date=2016-11-22 |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref> He died on August 18, 2013 after suffering a heart attack while on holiday in Antalya, Turkey.<ref>{{cite news|last=Childs|first=David|title=Obituary: Florin Cioaba: Activist and 'King of the Rroma'|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/florin-cioaba-activist-and-king-of-the-Rroma-8780991.html|work=The Independent|publisher=The Independent|accessdate=27 September 2013|location=London|date=22 August 2013}}</ref> He was succeeded as King by his son Dorin Cioabă.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.vice.com/article/an-audience-with-the-king-of-the-gypsies|title=An Audience With the 'King of the Gypsies'|publisher=Vice.com|author1=Sara Winston|author2=Martin Krupik|date=5 July 2014|accessdate=26 May 2015}}</ref>
===John Kyle=== In 2003, according to a decree issued by Emperor Iulian, John Kyle was proclaimed "International King of the Roma".<ref>{{cite news |title=La Mânăstirea Curtea de Argeş s-au sfinţit doar podoabele specifice rromilor |url=http://www.curierulnational.ro/?page=articol&editie=301&art=20984 |work=Curierul Naţional |date=September 3, 2003|language=ro}}</ref>
==Hungary== ===Tamás Bolgár=== He was named as voivode of the "Pharaoh's People" in 1496. He seems to have led a group of metalworkers, as he was supplying the Bishop of [[Pécs]] with cannonballs. He was almost certainly the same person granted privileges by the King of [[Poland]] and [[Lithuania]] in 1501, who also recognised the privileges of '''Wasili''' as leader of the "Cyhany"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amarodrom.hu/archivum/99/10/0.html|title=Záróra|date=31 December 2007|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=8 October 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071231132151/http://www.amarodrom.hu/archivum/99/10/0.html|archivedate=31 December 2007|df=}}</ref> <!-- of the 120 Rroma who arrived at Brassó, Kingdom of Hungary, (in German it called: Kronstadt, now Braşov, Romania) in 1516. -->
==Poland== ===Matiasz Korolewicz=== Was conferred the title "King of the Gypsies" by the Polish Royal Chancery in 1652, after the death of '''Janczy''' who had previously served as the head of the Roma. Later Kings of the Gypsies seem to have been appointed from the aristocracy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.romanothan.ro/romana/istorie/resurse_patrin.htm |title=Visitor anti-robot validation |website=Romanothan.ro |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref>
===Janusz Kwiek=== Was crowned as Janos I, King of the Gypsies, before thousands of people in 1937. He announced his intention to petition [[Benito Mussolini]] for land for a Romani settlement in [[East Africa]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.romahistory.com/en/2-5-11.htm|title=layout|date=27 September 2007|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=8 October 2017|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927195107/http://www.romahistory.com/en/2-5-11.htm|archivedate=27 September 2007|df=}}</ref>
==Bulgaria== ===Shibilis=== The Gypsy King is associated with mythical powers of being able to part water with his sword, a spade, and his head, after it had been cut off, according to tales collected in 1981.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://romaculture.cult.bg/DOCLAD.htm |title=ROMA IN BULGARIA AND THEIR FOLKLORE |last=Kolev |first=Deyan |author2=Teodora Krumova |date=January 14, 2002 |publisher=Protecting and Popularizing Roma Culture in Central Bulgaria |accessdate=2009-10-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050529140955/http://romaculture.cult.bg/DOCLAD.htm |archivedate=May 29, 2005 }}</ref>
==United States of America== ===M. H. Frank=== Who had lived in [[Meridian, Mississippi]], was chosen as King after Emil Mitchell's death in 1942.<ref>''Meridian Dispatch'' 7th February1915</ref><ref>''Meridian Star'' 5 August 1960</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sciway3.net/clark/freemoors/emilmitchell.html |title=Emil Mitchel Family |website=Sciway3.net |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://foclark.tripod.com/gypsy/rosehill.html |title=Free Moors and "Turks" in South Carolina |website=Foclark.tripod.com |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://foclark.tripod.com/gypsy/emilmitchell.html |title=Emil Mitchel Family |website=Foclark.tripod.com |date= |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref>
===Elijah George=== Described as king of the Gypsies at the time of the massive search for [[Elsie Paroubek]]. Mr. George was contacted in Argyle, Wisconsin, and taken to Joliet, Illinois for questioning; but he knew nothing and was released.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/386756031.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=May+9%2C+1911&author=&pub=Chicago+Daily+Tribune+%281872-1922%29&edition=&startpage=1&desc=CANAL+YIELDS+UP+BODY+OF+MISSING+ELSIE+PAROUBEK |title=Archives: Chicago Tribune - CANAL YIELDS UP BODY OF MISSING ELSIE PAROUBEK |website=Pqasb.pqarchiver.com |date=1911-05-09 |accessdate=2017-01-03}}</ref>
===Unidentified Romany=== In 1953, [[Anaïs Nin]] underwent surgery for ovarian cancer in a Los Angeles hospital. In her diary, she mentions that "the King of the Gypsies was having surgery at the same time" and that approximately six hundred members of his tribe were camped in or near the hospital in accordance with their law: "no amount of hospital discipline would drive them away". She spoke with several members of the band, and identified them as Romani people.<ref>Anaïs Nin, ''Diary Of Anaïs Nin Volume 5 1947-1955: Vol. 5 (1947-1955)'', p. 106-107.</ref>
==Venezuela== ===Angelo Vallerugo III=== Since 1998, Angelo Vallerugo III has been accepted by the Venezuelan gypsy community as their one and only king.<ref>Caceres, Jorge (1987). "Gypsys In Venezuela", 3rd ed., Santillana</ref>
==Further reading== * Angus Fraser (1995) ''The Gypsies'', 2nd ed., Oxford, {{ISBN|978-0-631-19605-1}}

{{Culture of England}} This '''list of cultural icons of England''' is a list of people and things from any period which are independently considered to be [[cultural icon]]s characteristic of [[England]]. {{Dynamic list}}
==Animals== [[File:Suffolk Plow Team.jpg|thumb|180px|[[Suffolk Punch]] horses]] * [[Dartmoor pony]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.heart.co.uk/exeter/news/local/dartmoor-pony-under-threat/ |title=Dartmoor pony under threat |author=Wendy Buckingham |date= |work= |publisher=[[Heart (radio network)|Heart]] |accessdate=16 February 2016}}</ref> * [[Exmoor pony]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.westernmorningnews.co.uk/Festival-celebrate-iconic-pony-Westcountry-moors/story-19452891-detail/story.html |title=Festival to celebrate an iconic pony of the Westcountry moors |author= |date=2 July 2013 |work= |publisher=[[Western Morning News]] |accessdate=16 February 2016}}</ref> * [[Gloucester Old Spot]] pig.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theabstract.co.uk/projects/theciderpress/page9/page31/page31.html |title=Orchard open day leaves visitors as happy as a pig in muck |author= |date=2011 |work= |publisher=The Cider Press |accessdate=16 February 2016}}</ref> * [[Hereford cattle]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ridgecattle.com/#!hereford/c18ip |title=Hereford Cattle |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Ridge Top Cattle |accessdate=16 February 2016}}</ref> * [[New Forest Pony]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/destinations/europe/united-kingdom/england/hampshire/new-forest/articles/National-Park-focus-the-New-Forest/ |title=National Park focus: the New Forest |author=Jolyon Attwooll |date=18 April 2013 |work= |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=16 February 2016}}</ref> * [[Black turkey|Norfolk turkey]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/news/could_norfolk_s_favourite_foods_become_protected_1_854127 |title=Could Norfolk's favourite foods become protected? |author=Stephanie Brooks |date=4 April 2011 |work= |publisher=[[Eastern Daily Press]] |accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref> * [[Old English sheepdog]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-20121304 |title=Old English Sheepdog put on breed watch list |author= |date=29 October 2012 |work= |publisher=[[BBC News Online]] |accessdate=16 February 2016}}</ref> * [[Suffolk Punch]] horse.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ipswichstar.co.uk/news/west_suffolk_revival_of_iconic_suffolk_punch_continues_1_3519625 |title=West Suffolk: Revival of iconic Suffolk Punch continues |author= |date=8 April 2014 |work= |publisher=[[Ipswich Star]] |accessdate=16 February 2016}}</ref>
==Art== {{main|English art}} [[File:Sir Arthur Wellesley Duke of Wellington.jpg|thumb|180px|[[Thomas Lawrence (painter)|Thomas Lawrence]]'s post-[[Battle of Waterloo|Waterloo]] portrait of [[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington|Wellington]]]] * [[William Blake]] (1757–1827).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://arthistorynewsreport.blogspot.co.uk/2013/06/william-blakes-masterpieces-at.html |title=William Blake's Masterpieces at Metropolitan Museum |author= |date=2013 |work= |publisher=Art History News |accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref> * [[John Constable]] (1776–1837);<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/10148768/Constables-The-Hay-Wain-targeted-by-Fathers4Justice-protester.html |title=Constable's ''The Hay Wain'' targeted by Fathers4Justice protester |author=Martin Evans |date=28 June 2013 |work= |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref> in particular, ''[[The Hay Wain]]''.<ref name=c24>{{cite web|url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/art362437 |title=ICONS of England – the 100 ICONS as voted by the public |publisher=[[Culture24]] |accessdate=21 June 2016}}</ref> * [[George Cruikshank]] (1792–1878).<ref name="rude">{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/bbc/7821648/Rude-Britannia-Britains-history-with-the-rude-and-subversive.html |title=Rude Britannia: Britain's history with the rude and subversive |date=2010 |work= |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=5 March 2018}}</ref> * [[Thomas Gainsborough]] (1727–1788).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tate.org.uk/about/press-office/press-releases/gainsborough-0 |title=Gainsborough |author= |date=2001 |work= |publisher=[[Tate]] |accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref> * [[James Gillray]] (1756/1757-1815).<ref name="rude"/> * [[Nicholas Hilliard]] (c. 1547–1619).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/10/31/telegraph-photographers-pictures-month-october/iconic-armada-portrait-elizabeth-hung-queens-house-greenwich/ |title=Telegraph photographers' pictures of the month: October |date=2017 |work= |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=5 March 2018}}</ref> * [[William Hogarth]] (1697–1764).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bristolmuseums.org.uk/bristol-museum-and-art-gallery/whats-on/william-hogarth-painter-printmaker/ |title=William Hogarth: Painter & Printmaker |author= |date=2015 |work= |publisher=[[Bristol City Museum and Art Gallery]] |accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref> * Sir [[Thomas Lawrence (painter)|Thomas Lawrence]] (1769–1830).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/8071704/Thomas-Lawrence-Regency-Power-and-Brilliance-National-Portrait-Gallery.html |title=Thomas Lawrence: Regency Power and Brilliance, National Portrait Gallery |date=2010 |work= |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=5 March 2018}}</ref> * [[L. S. Lowry]] (1887–1976).<ref name=c24/> * [[Henry Moore]] (1898–1986).<ref name=c24/> * Sir [[Joshua Reynolds]] (1723–1792).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://artdaily.com/news/58252/Birmingham-Museum---Art-Gallery-acquires-iconic-Sir-Joshua-Reynolds-work |title=Birmingham Museum & Art Gallery acquires iconic Sir Joshua Reynolds work |author= |date=2013 |work= |publisher=[[ArtDaily]] |accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref> * Sir [[James Thornhill]] (1675/76-1734).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person/mp04494/sir-james-thornhill |title=Sir James Thornhill |author= |date=2018 |work= |publisher=[[National Portrait Gallery, London]] |accessdate=5 March 2018}}</ref> * [[J. M. W. Turner]] (1775–1851).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pem.org/exhibitions/163-turner_the_sea |title=Turner & the Sea |author= |date=2014 |work= |publisher=[[Peabody Essex Museum]] |accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref> * [[Joseph Wright of Derby]] (1734–1797).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sothebys.com/en/auctions/ecatalogue/2011/old-master-and-british-paintings-evening-sale/lot.37.html |title=Joseph Wright of Derby, A.R.A. |author= |date=2016 |work= |publisher=[[Sotheby's]] |accessdate=29 February 2016}}</ref>
==Books and documents== [[File:1612 First Quarto of King James Bible.jpg|thumb|180px|[[King James Version|King James Bible]]]] [[File:Magna Carta (British Library Cotton MS Augustus II.106) - 02.jpg|thumb|180px|[[Magna Carta]]]] * The [[King James Version|King James Bible]] (begun 1604; completed 1611).<ref name=c24/> * The [[Bill of Rights 1689]] (passed on 16 December 1689).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.parliament.uk/about/living-heritage/evolutionofparliament/parliamentaryauthority/revolution/collections1/collections-glorious-revolution/billofrights/ |title=Bill of Rights 1689 |author= |date=2016 |work= |publisher=[[Parliament of the United Kingdom]] |accessdate=1 March 2016}}</ref> * ''[[The Canterbury Tales]]'' (produced between c. 1386 and 1400) by [[Geoffrey Chaucer]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://threegoldbees.com/otherarticlea/22-chaucerpardoner/ |title=A Portrait of the Pardoner from Chaucer's ''Canterbury Tales'' |author= |date=2016 |work= |publisher=Three Gold Bees |accessdate=1 March 2016}}</ref> * The [[Domesday Book]] (completed 1086).<ref name=c24/> * [[William Shakespeare]]'s [[First Folio]] (published posthumously in 1623).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bl.uk/press-releases/2015/september/british-literary-icons-to-be-exhibited-in-china-for-the-first-time |title=British literary icons to be exhibited in China for the first time |author= |date=2015 |work= |publisher=[[British Library]] |accessdate=1 March 2016}}</ref> * The [[Lindisfarne Gospels]] (produced c. 700 A.D.), attributed to [[Eadfrith of Lindisfarne]].<ref name=c24/> * ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' (begun 1937; completed 1949), by [[J. R. R. Tolkien]].<ref name=c24/> * [[Magna Carta]] (agreed by [[John, King of England|King John]] on 15 June 1215).<ref name=c24/> * ''[[Mrs Beeton's Book of Household Management]]'' (1861), edited by [[Isabella Beeton]].<ref name=c24/> * The [[Charles Dickens bibliography|novels]] of [[Charles Dickens]] (1812–1870).<ref name=c24/> * ''[[On the Origin of Species]]'' (1859) by [[Charles Darwin]].<ref name=c24/> * ''[[Our Island Story]]'' (1905) by [[Henrietta Elizabeth Marshall|H. E. Marshall]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/booksblog/2014/feb/07/our-island-story-conservative-david-cameron |title=''Our Island Story'': Not as Conservative as David Cameron imagines |author=Tom Holland |date=2014 |work= |publisher=[[theguardian.com|The Guardian Online]] |accessdate=1 March 2016}}</ref> * The ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' (begun 1857; first edition completed 1928).<ref name=c24/> * ''[[Pride and Prejudice]]'' (1813) by [[Jane Austen]].<ref name=c24/> * The works of [[Beatrix Potter]] (1866–1943).<ref name=c24/>
==Buildings and structures== [[File:Big Ben - geograph.org.uk - 1629575.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Big Ben]], a.k.a. the ''Elizabeth Tower'']] [[File:Home to criminals, princes and ravens - geograph.org.uk - 1600286.jpg|thumb|The [[Tower of London]]]] * The [[Abbey Road, London|Abbey Road]] [[zebra crossing]], famous for its association with [[the Beatles]]' 1969 album ''[[Abbey Road]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/iconic-abbey-road-crossing-made-271019 |title=Iconic Abbey Road crossing made famous by The Beatles awarded listed status |author= |date=2010 |work= |publisher=[[BBC News Online]] |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> * The [[Angel of the North]], contemporary sculpture by Sir [[Antony Gormley]], located near [[Gateshead]] in [[Tyne and Wear]] (completed 1998).<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/artblog/2008/feb/13/happybirthdayangeloftheno Guardian: Angel of the North]. Retrieved 15 December 2012.</ref><ref>[http://www.gateshead.gov.uk/Council%20and%20Democracy/news/News%20Articles/Angel%20of%20the%20North%20an%20English%20icon.aspx Gateshead Council: Angel of the North an English Icon]. Retrieved 15 December 2012.</ref><ref>[http://www.futurematters.org.uk/drivers/culturalregeneration.asp Future Matters: Cultural Regeneration]. Retrieved 15 December 2012. "The development of cultural icons such as Sage, Baltic and The Angel of the North have shown that iconic projects can go a long way to improving external perceptions of an area, as well as providing environmental, economic and social benefits."</ref> * [[Big Ben]] (the nickname for the bell; the clock tower of the [[Houses of Parliament]] was renamed the ''Elizabeth Tower'' in 2012).<ref>{{cite book | title=An Unstoppable Force: Daring to Become the Church God Had in Mind | publisher=Flagship Church Resources | author=McManus, Erwin Raphael | year=2001 | pages=113}}</ref> * [[Blackpool Tower]] (opened 14 May 1894).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-lancashire-14743747 |title=Blackpool Tower reopens to public after £20m restoration |author= |date=2011 |work= |publisher=[[BBC News Online]] |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> * [[Buckingham Palace]], London residence of the British monarch since 1837.<ref name="royal.uk">{{cite web|url=https://www.royal.uk/royal-residences-buckingham-palace|title=Buckingham Palace|author=Royal Household|website=Royal Family website|accessdate=21 April 2016}}</ref> * [[Canterbury Cathedral]] (founded 597; completely rebuilt 1070–1077; east end enlarged early 12th century, and largely rebuilt in [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] style following a fire in 1174).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://eastkentfreemasons.org/canterbury-cathedral-appeal/ |title=PGM Launches Canterbury Cathedral Appeal |author= |date=2015 |work= |publisher=[[Kent Museum of Freemasonry|East Kent Freemasons]] |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> * [[Durham Cathedral]], formally ''the Cathedral Church of Christ, Blessed Mary the Virgin and St Cuthbert of Durham'' (present cathedral founded 1093).<ref name=c24a>{{cite web |url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/history-and-heritage/art38995 |title=New List Of 20 More English Cultural Icons Announced |author= |date=2006 |work= |publisher=[[Culture24]] |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> * [[EMI]]'s [[The Old Vinyl Factory|Old Vinyl Factory]] in [[Hayes, Hillingdon|Hayes, Middlesex]], where records by [[The Beatles]] and other EMI artists were manufactured in the 1960s and after.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/news/local-news/one-off-gigs-iconic-old-vinyl-5974659 |title=One-off gigs at iconic Old Vinyl Factory |author=Jack Griffith |date=2012 |work= |publisher=GetWestLondon |accessdate=21 March 2016}}</ref> * [[Globe Theatre]] (the modern reconstruction, named "[[Shakespeare's Globe]]", opened in 1997 approximately 750 feet [230 m] from the site of the original[s]; the second Globe was pulled down 1644–45).<ref name=c24/> * [[Hadrian's Wall]] (begun in 122 A.D.).<ref name=c24/> * [[The Iron Bridge]], across the [[River Severn]] in [[Shropshire]] (opened 1781).<ref name=c24/> * The [[National Memorial Arboretum]], described by [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|Prince William]] in 2011 as an "iconic focal point" for the nation's remembrance of fallen soldiers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/prince-william/8883203/Prince-William-National-Memorial-Arboretum-an-iconic-focal-point.html |title=Prince William: National Memorial Arboretum 'an iconic focal point' |publisher= |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Pier#Pleasure piers|Seaside pier]]s (first built early 19th century).<ref name=c24/> * The [[Shaftesbury Memorial Fountain]], commemorating [[Anthony Ashley-Cooper, 7th Earl of Shaftesbury|Lord Shaftesbury]]; the statue of [[Anteros]] is named ''The Angel of Christian Charity''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/survey-london/vols31-2/pt2/pp101-110 |title=The Shaftesbury Memorial Fountain |publisher=[[British History Online]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Spaghetti junction]], or [[Gravelly Hill Interchange]]; opened 24 May 1972.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/work-restarts-to-protect-one-of-britains-most-iconic-road-structures |title=Work restarts to protect one of Britain's most iconic road structures |publisher=[[Gov.uk]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Stonehenge]], a [[prehistoric]] ring of [[standing stones]] in [[Wiltshire]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/visit/places/stonehenge/history/ | title = History of Stonehenge | publisher = [[English Heritage]] | access-date = 2016-06-07 }}</ref> * [[Tower of London]], officially ''Her Majesty's Royal Palace and Fortress of the Tower of London'' (the [[White Tower (Tower of London)|White Tower]] built 1078; expanded in the 12th & 13th centuries).<ref name=c24/> * [[Westminster Abbey]], formally ''the Collegiate Church of St Peter at Westminster'' (construction of the present church began 1245).<ref name=c24/> * [[York Minster]], formally ''the Cathedral and Metropolitical Church of Saint Peter in York'' (long history; the cathedral was declared complete and [[Consecration|consecrated]] 1472).<ref name=c24/>
==Clothing== [[File:Henry M Stanley 1872.jpg|thumb|150px|[[Henry Morton Stanley]] wearing a [[pith helmet]]]] * [[Blazer]], originated with the red 'blazers' of the [[Lady Margaret Boat Club]] (1825), the rowing club of [[St. John's College, Cambridge]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/men/fashion-and-style/10940463/Blazing-a-trail-the-origins-of-the-mens-blazer.html |title=Blazing a trail: the origins of the men's blazer |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[Bowler hat]], created 1849 for soldier and politician [[Edward Coke (1824–89)|Edward Coke]].<ref name=c24a/> * [[Deerstalker]] hat, popularly associated with representations of fictional private investigator [[Sherlock Holmes]]. * R. ==Transport==
===Cars=== [[File:Aston.db5.coupe (OA).PNG|thumb|200px|[[Aston Martin DB5]]]] * [[Aston Martin]], a manufacturer of [[Luxury vehicle|luxury]] [[sports car]]s and [[grand tourer]]s; associated since the 1960s with the fictional character [[James Bond]] following the use of a [[Aston Martin DB5|DB5]] model in the 1964 film ''[[Goldfinger (film)|Goldfinger]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/life/motoring/aston-martin-db5-named-the-most-iconic-british-car-of-all-time-28454422.html |title=Aston Martin DB5 named the most iconic British car of all time |publisher=''[[Belfast Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * The [[Ford Cortina]], built by [[Ford of Britain]] at [[Brentwood, Essex]] in various forms from 1962 to 1982.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2012/04/20/iconic-brand-new-ford-cortina-mk-v-up-for-sale-after-30-years-in-garage-395867/ |title=Iconic 'brand new' Ford Cortina MK V up for sale after 30 years in garage |publisher=''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]'' |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * The [[Jaguar E-Type]], manufactured by [[Jaguar Cars]] between 1961 and 1975. * [[Land Rover]], a car brand that specialises in [[four-wheel-drive]] vehicles; the ''Land Rover'' name was originally used, from 1948, by the [[Rover Company]].<ref name=c24/> * The [[Mini]], made by the [[British Motor Corporation]] and its successors 1959–2000.<ref name=c24/> * [[Morris Minor]] (1948–1971), recognised as typifying "Englishness". * [[Rolls-Royce Limited]] and [[Rolls-Royce Motors]], renowned car-manufacturers 1906–1998; exemplified by the [[Rolls-Royce Silver Shadow]];<ref name=c24/> and the associated [[Bentley]] (1919–1998; bought by Rolls-Royce in 1931).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.autocar.co.uk/car-news/industry/history-bentley-picture-special |title=History of Bentley – picture special |publisher=''[[Autocar (magazine)|Autocar]]'' |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref>
===Water=== [[File:The stern of HMS Victory - geograph.org.uk - 865432.jpg|thumb|200px|[[HMS Victory]]]] * [[Cutty Sark]] (1869): a [[Clipper|tea clipper]] built by 19th century ship-owning firm [[Jock Willis Shipping Line|John Willis & Sons of London]]; in dry dock at [[Greenwich]], London since 1954.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/cutty-sark-2-ship-lovers-plan-seaworthy-replica-of-iconic-19th-century-vessel-a6743811.html |title=Cutty Sark 2: Ship-lovers plan seaworthy replica of iconic 19th-century vessel |publisher=''[[The Independent]]'' |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * [[HMS Dreadnought (1906)|HMS Dreadnought]] (1906): a [[Royal Navy]] [[battleship]] that revolutionised naval power.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-27641717 |title=How the Dreadnought sparked the 20th Century's first arms race |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * The [[Golden Hind]]: an English [[galleon]] best known for Sir [[Francis Drake]]'s [[circumnavigation]] of the globe between 1577 and 1580;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indrakeswake.co.uk/Artefacts/goldenhind.htm |title=Searching for Sir Francis Drake's Golden Hind at Deptford, London |publisher=In Drake's Wake |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> the ship does not survive, but a replica – the [[Golden Hinde (1973)|Golden Hinde]] (1973) – has been berthed at St Mary Overie Dock on Cathedral Street, in [[Bankside]], [[London Borough of Southwark|Southwark]] since 1996. * The [[Mary Rose]]: King [[Henry VIII of England|Henry VIII]]'s [[warship]] sank on 19 July 1545 in the [[Solent]], the straits north of the [[Isle of Wight]]; the [[Shipwreck|wreck]] was rediscovered in 1971.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/museums/10088752/Life-and-death-on-the-Mary-Rose.html |title=Life and death on the Mary Rose |publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * The [[Mayflower]]: the ship that transported the first English [[Separatism|Separatist]]s, known today as the [[Pilgrim Fathers|Pilgrims]], from [[Plymouth]] to the [[New World]] in 1620. * [[Narrowboat]]s: the original working boats built in the 18th, 19th, and 20th centuries for carrying goods on England's narrow [[canal]]s.<ref name=c24/> * [[HMS Victory]]: best known as [[Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson|Lord Nelson]]'s [[flagship]] at the [[Battle of Trafalgar]] in 1805; in [[dry dock]] at [[Portsmouth]] since 1922.<ref name=c24/>
===Air=== [[File:SpitI19a.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Supermarine Spitfire]]]] * The [[Avro Lancaster]] (1941–1963). * [[Concorde]] (1969–2003), jointly developed and manufactured by the [[British Aircraft Corporation]] and [[Aérospatiale]] under an Anglo-French treaty. * The [[de Havilland Comet]] (1949–1997), the first commercial [[jet airliner]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/9889220/A-Great-British-Air-Disaster-Channel-4-review.html |title=A Great British Air Disaster, Channel 4, review |publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=20 June 2016}}</ref> and the [[Vickers VC10]] (1962–2013). * the [[Fairey Aviation Company]] (1915–1960). * The [[Hawker Siddeley Harrier]] (1969–2006). * The [[Sopwith Camel]] (1916–1920). * The [[Supermarine Spitfire]] (1936–1948) and the [[Hawker Hurricane]] (1935–1944).<ref name=c24/> [[File:Northern Routemaster.jpg|thumb|200px|[[AEC Routemaster]] bus]]

proceed.<ref name=c24/> * [[Pillar box|Red pillar box]]es (in use since 1852).<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/2294797.stm BBC article on English Heritage's preservation of them]</ref> * The [[Red telephone box]], dating from 1924.<ref name=c24/> * The [[Scouting|Scout movement]], created in 1907 by [[Robert Baden-Powell, 1st Baron Baden-Powell|Lord Baden-Powell]].<ref name=c24/> * The [[Seaside resort|seaside]] [[Pier|pleasure pier]], first built in England in the early 19th century.<ref name=c24/> * [[Stiff upper lip]], a display of [[Cardinal virtues|fortitude]] in the face of adversity, or an exercise of [[Self control|self-restraint]] in the expression of [[emotion]];<ref name=c24/> exemplified in [[Rudyard Kipling]]'s poem "[[If—]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/rudyard-kiplings-if-voted-nations-favourite-poem-1577258.html |title=Rudyard Kipling's 'If' voted nation's favourite poem |publisher=''[[The Independent]]'' |accessdate=16 August 2016}}</ref> * The [[Sutton Hoo helmet]], excavated in 1939 from a (c. 7th century) ship-burial and prompting comparisons with the world described in the heroic [[Old English]] poem ''[[Beowulf]]''.<ref name=c24/> * The London [[Tube Map]], designed originally in 1931 by [[Harry Beck]] (1902–1974).<ref name=c24/> * English [[Climate of the United Kingdom|weather]].<ref name=c24/> * The [[White Cliffs of Dover]]; of symbolic significance because they face [[Continental Europe]] across the narrowest part of the [[English Channel]], where invasions have historically threatened, and against which the cliffs form a symbolic guard; because crossing at Dover was the primary route to the continent before the advent of air travel, the white line of cliffs also formed the first or last sight of England for travellers.

{{About|the wives of Henry VIII|a more complete list of consorts|List of English consorts}} [[File:King Henry VIII from NPG (3).jpg|thumb|220px|A portrait of Henry VIII, painted c. 1520]] In legal terms, [[Henry VIII of England|King Henry VIII of England]] had only three wives, because three of his putative marriages were annulled. Unlike a divorce, where a married couple chooses to end their union, [[annulment|annulments]] essentially declare that a true marriage never took place.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/11358279/Henry-VIII-didnt-really-have-six-wives-why-everything-you-know-about-the-Tudors-is-wrong.html|title=Did Henry VIII really have six wives? Why everything you think you know about the Tudors is wrong|first=Olivia|last=Goldhill|date=26 January 2016|accessdate=26 January 2016|newspaper=The Daily Telegraphy}} However, in common parlance, the so-called '''wives of Henry VIII''' were the six [[queen consort|queens consort]] wedded to Henry between 1509 and his death in 1547. ==Overview== The six women who were married to Henry VIII were, in chronological order: {| class="wikitable" |- ! No. !! Name !! Married from - through !! Fate of marriage !! Fate of wife and issue |- | 1 || [[Catherine of Aragon]] || 11 June 1509 – 23 May 1533 || Annulled || Died 7 January 1536 while detained in [[Kimbolton Castle]].
Mother of [[Mary I of England|Mary I]]{{cite book |last1=Erickson |first1=Carolly |title=Great Harry: A Biography of Henry the VII |date=2007 |publisher=St. Martin's Press |isbn=0-312-16858-6 |page=48 |accessdate=23 September 2018}} |- | 2 || [[Anne Boleyn]] || 28 May 1533 – 17 May 1536 || Annulled || Beheaded 19 May 1536 at the [[Tower of London]].
Mother of [[Elizabeth I of England|Elizabeth I]] |- | 3 || [[Jane Seymour]] || 30 May 1536 – 24 October 1537 || Died || Died 24 October 1537, twelve days after giving birth due to complications.
Mother of [[Edward VI of England|Edward VI]] |- | 4 || [[Anne of Cleves]] || 6 January 1540 – 9 July 1540 || Annulled || Died possibly of cancer in 16 July 1557 |- | 5 || [[Catherine Howard]] || 28 July 1540 – 23 November 1541 || Beheaded || Beheaded 13 February 1542 at the Tower of London |- | 6 || [[Catherine Parr]] || 12 July 1543 – 28 January 1547 || Widowed || Survived Henry VIII. Later remarried to Thomas Seymour. Died 7 September 1548.{{cite web |last1=Hanson |first1=Marilee |title=Katherine Parr --Facts, Information, Biography & Portraits |url=https://englishhistory.net/tudor/monarchs/katharine-parr/ |website=English History |accessdate=23 September 2018 |date=31 January 2015}} |} Henry's first marriage lasted nearly 24 years; the five that followed less than 10 years combined. A common [[mnemonic device]] to remember the fates of Henry's consorts is "Divorced, beheaded, died, divorced, beheaded, survived". There are also two rhymes:{{cn|date=June 2017}}{{year needed|date=June 2017}} {{quote|King Henry VIII, To six wives he was wedded. One died, one survived, Two divorced, two beheaded.}} and {{quote|Boleyn and Howard lost their heads, Anne of Cleves he would not bed, Jane Seymour gave him a son – but died before the week was done, Aragon he did divorce, Which just left Catherine Parr, of course!}} It is often noted that [[Catherine Parr]] "survived him." In fact, [[Anne of Cleves]] also survived the king, and was the last of his queens to die. Of the six queens, [[Catherine of Aragon|Katherine of Aragon]], [[Anne Boleyn]], and [[Jane Seymour]] each gave Henry one child who survived infancy: two daughters and one son. All three of these children would eventually ascend to the throne: [[Edward VI of England|King Edward VI]], [[Mary I of England|Queen Mary I]], and [[Elizabeth I of England|Queen Elizabeth I]]. Catherine Howard and Anne Boleyn, the two of Henry's queens who were beheaded, were first cousins. Several of Henry's wives worked in at least one of his other wives' service, typically as [[lady-in-waiting|ladies-in-waiting]]: Anne Boleyn worked in Catherine of Aragon's service, Jane Seymour worked in Catherine of Aragon's and Anne Boleyn's, and Catherine Howard worked in Anne of Cleves's. Henry and at least four of his wives (Catherine of Aragon, Anne Boleyn, Jane Seymour, and Catherine Parr) were portrayed in [[List of historical opera characters|opera]]. ==Katherine of Aragon== {{Main article|Katherine of Aragon}} [[File:Catherine aragon.jpg|150px|right|thumb|Katherine of Aragon]] [[Catherine of Aragon|Katherine of Aragon]] (16 December 1485{{spaced ndash}}7 January 1536; {{lang-es|link=no|Catalina de Aragón}}) was Henry's first wife. Although her name is sometimes spelled ''Catherine'', Katherine of Aragon spelled and signed her name with a "K," which was the accepted spelling in England.{{Cite web|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catherine_of_Aragon#Spelling_of_her_name|title=Catherine of Aragon|last=Wikipedia|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{circular inline|date=October 2018}}{{Cite book|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-4891|title=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|last=Davies|first=C.S.L.|last2=Edwards|first2=John|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2011|isbn=|location=England|pages=|doi=10.1093/ref:odnb/4891|chapter-url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-4891|doi-access=Free|chapter=Katherine [Catalina, Catherine, Katherine of Aragon] (1485-1536)}} After the death of [[Arthur, Prince of Wales|Arthur]], her first husband and Henry's brother, a [[papal dispensation]] was obtained to enable her to marry Henry, though the marriage did not take place until after he came to the throne in 1509. Prospects were looking good when Katherine became pregnant in 1510, just 4 months after their marriage, but the girl was stillborn. Katherine became pregnant again in 1511, and gave birth to a boy, [[Henry, Duke of Cornwall]], who died almost two months later. In 1513, Katherine gave birth to a stillborn boy, and gave birth to a boy who died within hours in 1515. Finally, Katherine bore him a healthy daughter in 1516, [[Mary I of England|Mary]]. It took her two years to conceive again. This pregnancy ended in a short-lived girl. It is said that Henry truly loved Katherine of Aragon, as he himself professed it many times in declarations, etc. Henry, at the time a Roman Catholic, sought the Pope's approval for an [[annulment]] on the grounds that his marriage was invalid because Katherine had first been his brother's wife, using a passage from the Old Testament (Leviticus Chapter 20 Verse 21) to justify his stance: "If a man shall take his brother’s wife, it is an impurity; he hath uncovered his brother’s nakedness; they shall be childless.” Henry had begun an affair with [[Anne Boleyn]], who is said{{by whom|date=July 2016}} to have refused to become his mistress (Henry had already consummated an affair then dismissed Anne's sister, [[Mary Boleyn]], and most historians believe that Anne wanted to avoid the same treatment){{Citation needed|date=October 2010}}. Despite the pope's refusal, Henry separated from Katherine in 1531. In the face of the Pope's continuing refusal to annul his marriage to Katherine, Henry ordered the highest church official in England, [[Thomas Cranmer]], [[Archbishop of Canterbury]], to convene a court to rule on the status of his marriage to Katherine. On 23 May 1533,Lacey Baldwin Smith, Henry VIII: The Mask of Royalty, p. 116 Cranmer ruled the marriage to Katherine null and void. On 28 May 1533, he pronounced the King legally married to Anne (with whom Henry had already secretly exchanged wedding vows, probably in late January 1533). This led to the break from the Roman Catholic Church and the later establishment of the [[Church of England]]. [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]] called Katherine "The Queen of Earthly Queens." Marriage to Henry VIII: 11 June 1509 – 23 May 1533 (23 years, 11 months, 19 days); marriage annulled. ==Anne Boleyn== {{Main article|Anne Boleyn}} [[File:Anne boleyn.jpg|150px|right|thumb|Anne Boleyn]] [[Anne Boleyn]] (c.1501/1507{{spaced ndash}}19 May 1536) was Henry's second wife and the mother of [[Elizabeth I of England|Elizabeth I]]. Henry's marriage to Anne, and her subsequent execution, made her a key figure in the political and religious upheaval that was the start of the [[English Reformation]]. The daughter of Sir [[Thomas Boleyn, 1st Earl of Wiltshire|Thomas Boleyn]] and his wife, [[Elizabeth Boleyn, Countess of Wiltshire|Lady Elizabeth Boleyn]] (born Lady Elizabeth Howard), Anne was of nobler birth than [[Jane Seymour]], Henry's later wife. She was dark-haired, with beautiful features and lively manners; she was educated in Europe, largely as a [[lady-in-waiting]] to [[Claude of France|Queen Claude of France]]. Anne resisted the King's attempts to seduce her in 1526 and she refused to become his mistress, as her sister, [[Mary Boleyn]], had been. It soon became the one absorbing object of the King's desires to secure a divorce from his wife, [[Catherine of Aragon]], so he could marry Anne. Evidence of intimacy between the King and Anne is found in a love letter written by the King, in which he expressed admiration for her "pretty duckies" (breasts).{{cite web|url=http://www.luminarium.org/renlit/henrytoanne.htm|title=Love Letter of King Henry VIII to Anne Boleyn, 1533.|website=www.luminarium.org}} When it became clear that [[Pope Clement VII]] was unlikely to give the king an annulment, the breaking of the power of the Roman Catholic Church in England began. Henry had [[Thomas Wolsey]] dismissed from public office and later had the Boleyn family's chaplain, [[Thomas Cranmer]], appointed [[Archbishop of Canterbury]]. In 1533, Henry and Anne went through a secret wedding service."Anne Boleyn 1507–1536." World Book Encyclopedia. "19th ed". 2001. Print. She soon became pregnant and there was a second, public wedding service, which took place in London on 25 January 1533. On 23 May 1533, Cranmer declared the marriage of Henry and Catherine null and void. Five days later, Cranmer declared the marriage of Henry and Anne to be good and valid. Soon after, the Pope launched sentences of [[excommunication]] against the King and the Archbishop. As a result of Anne's marriage to the King, the [[Church of England]] was forced to break with Rome and was brought under the king's control. Anne was crowned [[List of English consorts|Queen Consort of England]] on 1 June 1533. Later that year, on 7 September, Anne gave birth to Henry's second daughter, [[Elizabeth I of England|Elizabeth]]. When Anne failed to quickly produce a male heir, her only son being stillborn, the King grew tired of her, annulled their marriage, and a plot was hatched by [[Thomas Cromwell, 1st Earl of Essex|Thomas Cromwell]] to execute her. Although the evidence against her was unconvincing, Anne was beheaded on charges of [[adultery]], [[incest]], and [[high treason]] on 19 May 1536. Following her daughter [[Elizabeth I of England|Elizabeth]]'s coronation as queen, Anne was venerated as a martyr and heroine of the English Reformation, particularly through the works of [[John Foxe]]. Over the centuries, Anne has inspired or been mentioned in numerous [[Anne Boleyn in popular culture|artistic and cultural works]]. Marriage to Henry VIII: 28 May 1533{{spaced ndash}}17 May 1536 (2 years, 11 months, 19 days); annulled, then beheaded.{{cite web|url=http://tudorhistory.org/boleyn/|title=Anne Boleyn|website=tudorhistory.org}} ==Jane Seymour== {{Main article|Jane Seymour}} [[File:Hans Holbein the Younger - Jane Seymour, Queen of England - Google Art Project.jpg|150px|right|thumb|Jane Seymour]] [[Jane Seymour]] (c.roughly 1508{{spaced ndash}}24 October 1537) was Henry's third wife. She served [[Catherine of Aragon]] and was one of [[Anne Boleyn|Anne Boleyn's]] ladies-in-waiting.Jokinen, Anniina. "[http://www.luminarium.org/renlit/sixwives.htm The Six Wives of King Henry VII]" 2007. Web. 7 May 2009. It is strongly believed{{who|date=December 2014}} that she is the mistress who disposed of Anne, who was executed just 10–11 days before Jane's marriage to the king. The daughter of a knight, she was of lower birth than most of Henry's wives. Finally, a year later, Jane gave birth to a healthy, legitimate male heir, [[Edward VI of England|Edward]], but she died twelve days later, presumably because of post-natal complications. This apparently caused her husband genuine grief, as she was the only queen to receive a proper Queen's burial; when the King died in 1547, he was buried next to her. Marriage to Henry VIII: 30 May 1536{{spaced ndash}}24 October 1537 (1 year, 4 months, 24 days); death from complications of childbirth. ==Anne of Cleves== {{Main article|Anne of Cleves}} [[File:AnneCleves.jpg|150px|right|thumb|Anne of Cleves]] [[Anne of Cleves]] (22 September 1515{{spaced ndash}}16 July 1557) was Henry's fourth wife, for only six months in 1540, from 6 January to 9 July. Anne of Cleves was a German princess."Anne of Cleves." World Book Encyclopedia. "19th ed". 2001. Print. It has been stated that Henry referred to her as "''A Flanders Mare''", which may or may not be true; nevertheless, the label has stuck with Anne.Burnett "History of the Reformation of England" Print Her pre-contract of marriage with [[Francis I, Duke of Lorraine]], was cited as grounds for an annulment. Anne agreed to this, claiming that the marriage had not been consummated, and because she hadn't resisted the annulment, was given a generous settlement, including [[Hever Castle]], former home of Henry's former in-laws, the Boleyns. She was given the name "The King's Sister", and became a friend to him and his children until his death. She outlived both the King and his last two wives, making her the last of the six wives to die. Marriage to Henry VIII: 6 January 1540{{spaced ndash}}9 July 1540 (6 months, 3 days); annulled. ==Catherine Howard== {{Main article|Catherine Howard}} [[File:HowardCatherine02.jpeg|150px|right|thumb|Catherine Howard]] [[Catherine Howard]] (c.1521{{spaced ndash}}13 February 1542) was Henry's fifth wife between 1540–1542, sometimes known as "the rose without a thorn". Henry was informed of her alleged adultery with [[Thomas Culpeper]] on 1 November 1541."Catherine Howard." World Book Encyclopaedia. "19th ed". 2001. Print. Marriage to Henry VIII: 28 July 1540{{spaced ndash}}23 November 1541 (1 year, 3 months, 26 days); beheaded. ==Catherine Parr== {{Main article|Catherine Parr}} [[File:Catherine Parr from NPG.jpg|150px|right|thumb|Catherine Parr]] [[Catherine Parr]] (1512{{spaced ndash}}5 September 1548), also spelled Kateryn, was the sixth and last wife of Henry VIII, 1543–1547. She was the daughter of [[Sir Thomas Parr]] of Kendal and his wife [[Maud Green]]. Through her father, Catherine was a descendant of [[John of Gaunt]], son of King [[Edward III of England|Edward III]]. Through John of Gaunt's daughter [[Joan Beaufort, Countess of Westmoreland]] (Henry's great-great grandmother), she was Henry's third cousin, once removed. By Henry's paternal descent from another of John of Gaunt's children, [[John Beaufort, 1st Earl of Somerset]], the two were also fourth cousins once removed.{{cite web |last=Lundy |first=Darryl |url=http://www.thepeerage.com/e274.htm |title= e274.htm |publisher= The Peerage}}{{Unreliable source?|failed=y |date=February 2013}} Catherine showed herself to be the restorer of Henry's court as a family home for his children. Catherine was determined to present the royal household as a close-knit one in order to demonstrate strength through unity to Henry's opposers.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} Perhaps Catherine's most significant achievement was Henry's passing of an [[Third Succession Act|act]] that confirmed both [[Mary I of England|Mary]]'s and [[Elizabeth I of England|Elizabeth]]'s line in succession for the throne, despite the fact that they had both been made illegitimate by divorce or remarriage. Such was Henry's trust in Catherine that he chose her to rule as Regent while he was attending to the [[Italian War of 1542–46|war in France]] and in the unlikely event of the loss of his life, she was to rule as Regent until nine-year-old [[Edward VI of England|Edward]] came of age. Catherine also has a special place in history as she was the most married queen of England, having had four husbands in all; Henry was her third. She had been widowed twice before marrying Henry. After Henry's death, she married [[Thomas Seymour, 1st Baron Seymour of Sudeley|Thomas Seymour]], uncle of [[Edward VI of England]], to whom she had formed an attachment prior to her marriage with Henry. She had one child by Seymour, [[Mary Seymour|Mary]], and died shortly after childbirth. Lady Mary's history is unknown, but she is not believed to have survived childhood. Marriage to Henry VIII: 12 July 1543{{spaced ndash}}28 January 1547 (3 years, 6 months, 16 days); his death at the age of 55. ==Ancestry== Henry was distantly related to all six of his wives through their common ancestor, King [[Edward I of England]],Antonia Fraser, ''The Wives of Henry VIII'', genealogical tables through more than one ancestor.{{cite web|url=https://tudorqueen6.com/2012/09/22/english-ancestry-of-the-six-wives-descent-from-edward-i/|title=English Ancestry of The Six Wives: Descent from Edward I|date=22 September 2012|publisher=}} The following family tree of Henry VIII's six wives is the closest lineage of him. {{familytree/start}} {{familytree | | | | | | | | | | | | | Ed |Ed=1239–1307
